results.headline: A Misanthrope and His Crumbling Castle
results.display_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun

results.summary_short: In “The Monastery: Mr. Vig & the Nun,” Jorgen Lauersen Vig comes across as a hybrid of quasi-Dickensian curmudgeon and modern grumpy old man.

results.headline: Seeking Glory, and Fighting Evil, With a Paddle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Balls of Fury

results.summary_short: “Balls of Fury” is raunchier and somewhat more imaginative than “Hot Rod,” and it will be must viewing for Christopher Walken completists.

results.headline: Martial Arts With a Gun Instead of a Kick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War

results.summary_short: Today, it seems, anyone seeking a pleasant summer afternoon of Asian-style fisticuffs must settle for the kind of urban-action/martial-arts hybrid that is “War.”

results.headline: A New Home With a Stepford Vibe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bothersome Man

results.summary_short: A surreal nightmare of gleaming surfaces and razor-sharp edges, “The Bothersome Man” unfolds in a sterile city where nothing is quite as it seems.

results.headline: Adventures in Real Estate

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Closing Escrow

results.summary_short: Despite their quirks, the three real estate agents and their clients — three couples in search of a dream home — featured in “Closing Escrow” are improbably endearing.

results.headline: Trouble at Sea

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deep Water

results.summary_short: The documentary “Deep Water” begins like a Boy’s Own adventure tale but ends up more akin to tragedy.

results.headline: The Gritty City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skid Row

results.summary_short: More vérité than cinema, the documentary “Skid Row” is so raw that it’s virtually unwatchable.

results.headline: Heroes and Has-Beens in Redemption City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resurrecting the Champ

results.summary_short: “Resurrecting the Champ” is a cautionary fable that every journalistic go-getter dreaming of front-page bylines would do well to heed.

results.headline: The Devil Wears Down Her Nanny

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nanny Diaries

results.summary_short: As “The Nanny Diaries” wobbles along uncertainly, it rests on the tense, squared shoulders of Laura Linney.

results.headline: A Place for Rebirth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kamp Katrina

results.summary_short: “Kamp Katrina” chronicles a married couple who  opened their backyard to displaced people on the condition that they find jobs.

results.headline: Losing Gun Contol

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Illegal Tender

results.summary_short: Luridly earnest and laughably immoral, “Illegal Tender” is an old genre movie with a new look. Call it Hispanixploitation.

results.headline: The Passion Is Plentiful, and So Is the Angst

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hottest State

results.summary_short: “The Hottest State” doggedly peels away the gloss to dive into the emotional swamp where two young people get lost in each other.

results.headline: Terror and Duct Tape

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Right at Your Door

results.summary_short: “Right at Your Door” is  a doomsday-style film by Chris Gorak with a twist worth waiting for.

results.headline: In a World of Heartbreak, He’s a Catch (Quirks a Plus)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dedication

results.summary_short: That weird exhalation you hear at the multiplex these days is the sound of female characters settling for less than they deserve. It happens again in “Dedication.”

results.headline: Mormons Who Massacre

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of September Dawn

results.summary_short: The maudlin, grotesque western “September Dawn” apes “Schindler’s List” in hopes of creating a Christian Holocaust picture.

results.headline: Pratfalls in Every Language

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Bean's Holiday

results.summary_short: With “Mr. Bean’s Holiday,” the British comedian Rowan Atkinson continues a tradition that in the right hands never gets stale: comic pantomime.

results.headline: Three Relationships, Seen Through a D.I.Y. Lens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Takes the Stairs

results.summary_short: “Hannah Takes the Stairs” is notable for what the movie represents: an evolutionary entry in the Do It Yourself (or D.I.Y.) independent film movement.

results.headline: He Came, He Saw, He Wimped Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Legion

results.summary_short: This sword-and-sandal spectacle from those epic-loving De Laurentiises might have made a good children’s film.

results.headline: For Three Virgins, the Path to Sunrise Is Paved With Excess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Superbad

results.summary_short: Horny is as horny does in the sweetly absurd high school comedy “Superbad.”

results.headline: Life and Country in Upheaval

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunflower

results.summary_short: Like Douglas Sirk without the throw pillows, “Sunflower” is a shamelessly old-fashioned melodrama performed with such sincerity that resistance is futile.
